meta.title: NYC Government Structure
meta.description: Visualization of entities established under the NYC Charter and the five borough governments.

nodes.label: NYC Charter
nodes.factoid: Foundational document defining the structure and powers of New York City government.

nodes.label: Mayor
nodes.factoid: Elected citywide executive. Oversees agencies, prepares the budget, and enforces city laws.

nodes.label: Comptroller
nodes.factoid: Fiscal watchdog and auditor. Oversees the city's financial operations and pensions.

nodes.label: Public Advocate
nodes.factoid: Monitors city agencies and acts as a public ombudsman, representing residents before city government.

nodes.label: City Council
nodes.factoid: 51-member legislative body that passes local laws, approves the budget, and exercises oversight.

nodes.label: NYC Departments & Agencies
nodes.factoid: Agencies responsible for carrying out policy across housing, health, planning, education, and more.

nodes.label: Administrative Code (NYC Statute)
nodes.factoid: Compilation of permanent local laws enacted by the City Council and signed by the Mayor.

nodes.label: Rules of the City of New York (Administrative Law)
nodes.factoid: Regulations issued by city agencies to implement provisions of the Administrative Code.

nodes.label: NYC Budget
nodes.factoid: Annual financial plan allocating operating and capital funds across city agencies and boroughs.

nodes.label: Manhattan
nodes.factoid: Manhattan's Borough President oversees 12 Community Boards, representing local neighborhoods.

nodes.label: Brooklyn
nodes.factoid: Brooklyn's Borough President oversees 18 Community Boards.

nodes.label: Bronx
nodes.factoid: Bronx's Borough President oversees 12 Community Boards.

nodes.label: Queens
nodes.factoid: Queens's Borough President oversees 14 Community Boards.

nodes.label: Staten Island
nodes.factoid: Staten Island's Borough President oversees 3 Community Boards.

nodes.label: Community Boards
nodes.factoid: Each community board has at most 50 members
